title-group.article-title: GDSMOTE: A Novel Synthetic Oversampling Method for High-Dimensional Imbalanced Financial Data

abstract.p: Synthetic oversampling methods for dealing with imbalanced classification problems have been widely studied. However, the current synthetic oversampling methods still cannot perform well when facing high-dimensional imbalanced financial data. The failure of distance measurement in high-dimensional space, error accumulation caused by noise samples, and the reduction of recognition accuracy of majority samples caused by the distribution of synthetic samples are the main reasons that limit the performance of current methods. Taking these factors into consideration, a novel synthetic oversampling method is proposed, namely the gradient distribution-based synthetic minority oversampling technique (GDSMOTE). Firstly, the concept of gradient contribution was used to assign the minority-class samples to different gradient intervals instead of relying on the spatial distance. Secondly, the root sample selection strategy of GDSMOTE avoids the error accumulation caused by noise samples and a new concept of nearest neighbor was proposed to determine the auxiliary samples. Finally, a safety gradient distribution approximation strategy based on cosine similarity was designed to determine the number of samples to be synthesized in each safety gradient interval. Experiments on high-dimensional imbalanced financial datasets show that GDSMOTE can achieve a higher F1-Score and MCC metrics than baseline methods while achieving a higher recall score. This means that our method has the characteristics of improving the recognition accuracy of minority-class samples without sacrificing the recognition accuracy of majority-class samples and has good adaptability to data decision-making tasks in the financial field.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Many datasets in binary classification scenarios suffer from the problem of class imbalance, where the number of samples in one class far exceeds that of another class. The class with a large sample size is called the majority class or negative class, while the other class is called the minority class or positive class. For example, the number of non-default samples (negative class) in credit default prediction datasets [1] is usually much larger than that of default samples (positive class). Similar scenarios include fraud consumption detection [2] in the financial sector, abnormal traffic detection [3] in network security, fault diagnosis [4] in industrial systems, etc. With the increasing demand for intelligence in these scenarios, imbalanced classification is also increasingly receiving more attention in the field of artificial intelligence.

Class imbalance problems can lead to a decrease in the recognition rate of classifiers for positive-class samples, but the special nature of the scene usually requires the model to have relatively good recognition performance for positive classes. The characteristic of supervised machine learning is that the ability of a classifier to learn sample patterns is directly proportional to the number of samples, and the recognition performance of a classifier for one class depends on the contribution of this class to classifier optimization. However, under the conditions of class imbalance, the absolute advantage of the negative-class samples in terms of quantity makes a significant contribution to the fitting of the classifier, resulting in a good fitting result for the negative-class samples, while the opposite is true for positive-class samples. Although the overall performance of the classifier appears to be excellent, the recognition performance of positive-class samples is very pessimistic.

Oversampling technology for positive-class data has become the first research direction to alleviate the problem of class imbalance [5,6]. This technology makes the number of samples of the negative class and the positive class roughly equal by synthesizing a certain number of pseudo-samples of the positive-class samples. The synthetic minority oversampling technique (SMOTE) [7] is the most popular and widely used synthetic oversampling method, which randomly selects a sample among the k nearest neighbors of the root sample as an auxiliary sample and synthesizes pseudo-samples using the interpolation method. Many optimization algorithms based on SMOTE have also emerged, including KMeans-SMOTE, Borderline-SMOTE [8], ADASYN [9], SVM-SMOTE [10], Safe-Level-SMOTE [11], etc. These methods have improved SMOTE in terms of determining root samples and synthetic weights. In addition to the synthetic oversampling method, [12] adopted the sample adaptive weight method to deal with the class imbalance problem in speech emotion recognition.

Due to the particularity of financial activities, the datasets in credit default prediction, precision marketing, fraudulent consumption detection, and other scenarios not only have the characteristics of class imbalance but also have the characteristics of high dimensionality. However, the high-dimensional characteristics of samples limit the effectiveness of spatial neighbor search, clustering, and other methods [13], meaning that these methods, which rely on the spatial distribution of samples, cannot effectively solve the oversampling problem of real datasets. As shown in Figure 1, when the 30-dimensional real data are reduced to four dimensions, DBSCAN and OPTICS methods cannot obtain effective sub-clusters. When the data are forced to be divided into three sub-clusters and four sub-clusters by K-means, the clustering results are shown in Figure 1b, where dots of different colors represent different sub-clusters, the boundary of each sub-cluster is still very unclear. That is, the samples at the boundary of sub-clusters do not have good spatial distribution characteristics. This severely affects the performance of methods that rely on spatial distributions.

To overcome the problems in existing works and inspired by the research results in the field of image imbalance classification [14], which achieved good classification results by weighting samples of different classes using gradient norms, we propose a synthetic oversampling algorithm GDSMOTE based on safety gradient distribution. This method maintains the consistent distribution of oversampled positive-class samples and original positive-class data within the safety gradient intervals. Firstly, the gradient contribution metric of samples (referred to as the gradient), which does not depend on the spatial distribution, was designed, which was used to divide positive-class samples into different intervals. Secondly, a safety gradient threshold is set to divide positive-class samples into safety gradient intervals and danger gradient intervals. Samples within the safety gradient interval are selected as root samples, and the gradient right nearest neighbors of those root samples are selected as auxiliary samples. Finally, the number of samples synthetized for each safety gradient interval is determined by the principle of gradient distribution approximation. The GDSMOTE method proposed in this paper can be applied to many financial scenarios, such as precision marketing of financial products, credit default prediction, fraud consumption detection, etc. These datasets are often characterized by high dimensionality and class imbalance.

Compared to current research work, the main contributions of our work are as follows:
A new sample classification metric, gradient contribution, is designed for the synthetic oversampling method. The metric is calculated by the gradient contribution of the sample to the classifier, and does not depend on the spatial distribution, which overcomes a series of problems caused by the difficulty of distance measurement in high-dimensional space.
A novel root sample selection strategy for the synthetic oversampling method has been designed. Samples within the safety gradient intervals are selected as root samples, rather than samples near the decision boundary. This strategy not only avoids the accumulation of errors in noisy samples to a certain extent but also avoids the problem of fuzzy decision boundaries caused by generating samples near the decision boundary.
A new calculation principle of the number of synthetic samples, safety gradient distribution approximation, is designed. For the purpose of ensuring that the synthetic new sample fell into the same gradient interval as the root sample, the gradient right nearest neighbors of root samples are selected as auxiliary samples, and the number of synthetic samples for each safety gradient interval was determined by the gradient distribution of the positive-class samples.
Combining the above three innovative points, our work proposes a synthetic oversampling algorithm framework based on the safety gradient GDSMOTE. GDSMOTE can not only improve the recognition performance of positive-class samples, but also makes the recognition ability between classes more balanced.

The other contents of our work are arranged as follows. The literature work related to the research topic of this paper is described in Section 2. In Section 3, the GDSMOTE method is introduced in detail, including the implementation idea, the overall framework, and the algorithm flow. Section 4 introduces the experimental datasets, benchmark methods, evaluation metrics, and the analysis of the experimental results of this paper. Our conclusions and future research directions are discussed in Section 5.

sec.title: 2. Research Background
sec.p: Recent research on the synthetic oversampling method is divided into four directions, namely feature space improvement, adaptive synthesis, clustering synthesis, and filtering synthesis. The specific related works are introduced in Section 2.1, Section 2.2, Section 2.3 and Section 2.4, and these works are summarized in Section 2.5.

sec.title: 2.1. Spatial Feature Optimization
sec.p: BDO [15] calculates the degree to which each sample was treated as a boundary sample based on its information entropy. The Sigma rule is used to quantify the boundary degree and select the negative boundary samples, indirectly selecting positive boundary samples for oversampling. At the same time, BDO iteratively synthesizes the auxiliary boundary points along the deceptive gradient, finally oversampling new samples between the positive boundary samples and the auxiliary boundary points. NaNSMOTE [16] proposed the SMOTE method based on natural neighbors. It is not limited by the parameters of the SMOTE method, the distribution of synthetic samples is more reasonable due to natural neighbor differences between central and boundary samples, and NaNSMOTE can also reduce the error of noisy samples. The local density is calculated in NLDAO [17] by the natural neighborhood and it identifies samples that make the classification boundary clearer and distributes the generated samples to the positive class unevenly. Its synthetic dataset is also more robust to noise. WRND [18] can be said to be an optimization of many SMOTE-based oversampling algorithms. It identifies noise samples and abnormal samples by natural neighbors, and allocates the number and distribution of synthetic samples according to the relative neighborhood density distribution of original samples.

sec.title: 2.2. Adaptive Weighted Synthesis
sec.p: NanBDOS [19] is an improvement of NaNSMOTE that adaptively assigns dynamic weights to original samples when searching natural neighborhoods. Consequently, a more valid neighborhood relationship is established and the distribution characteristics of original samples are maintained to a greater extent. LDAS [20] has an adaptive strategy similar to NanBDOS, but instead of synthesizing new samples for samples in a specific region, LDAS adaptively weights oversampling based on its proximity to the decision boundary and local density. The authors of [21] proposed an adaptive oversampling method guided by the mean shift method, which considered the sample distribution in the radius neighborhood of the positive-class sample and then adaptively determined the number of synthetic positive-class samples by combining the density of the positive-class samples and the distance from the negative-class samples. MAO [22] is a multiple adaptive oversampling method, which performs multiple adaptive oversampling of positive-class samples to balance the sample distribution, then trains sub-classifiers with different weights on datasets with different imbalance rates, and finally corrects the labels of samples that are difficult to identify by neighborhood information. AFNFS [23] can automatically select key features according to the fuzzy neighborhood method. It constructs the adaptive fuzzy neighborhood joint entropy by calculating the variance matrix and the fuzzy neighborhood radius, which is used to mine the distribution information of the original sample.

sec.title: 2.3. Synthesis Based on Clustering
sec.p: OEGFCM-SMOTE [24] applies the optimal entropy genetic C-means to the synthetic oversampling method. Fuzzy C-means is used to identify safe samples and filtered noise samples based on spatial characteristics in the original positive-class samples. The sample is synthesized based on the imbalance rate threshold and data distribution metric, and OEGFCM-SMOTE provided an optimal combination solution method for its four parameters. SMOTE-COF [25] has improved the SMOTE method through the center offset factor. Positive-class samples were divided into different sub-clusters by spatial distance and new samples were synthesized within these sub-clusters by their sparse degree. AWTDO [26] first uses the K-Means method to divide all samples into different sub-clusters with various imbalance rates, then divides all sub-clusters into positive, boundary, and negative domains, and finally calculates oversampling weights for each sub-cluster based on imbalance rates and domain attributes.

sec.title: 2.4. Synthesis Based on Filtering
sec.p: GMF-SMOTE [27] is a new algorithm that uses the Gaussian mixture model as the filtering method, which groups the original dataset according to the expected maximum method of the Gaussian mixture model. The expected maximum algorithm is also used to filter the noise samples in each group, and positive-class samples are synthesized in each group by designing a dynamic sampling rate. SMOTE-NaN-DE [28] is an optimization method after synthesis oversampling by SMOTE. After positive samples are synthesized by SMOTE, it identifies the noise sample according to the natural neighborhood distribution and then optimizes the location of the noise sample by using differential evolution. The authors of [29] proposed a re-labeling sampling method, which does not synthesize positive-class samples but filters out suspected positive-class samples from negative-class samples and achieves class balance by re-labeling these samples. Therefore, it has the characteristics of independent spatial features. Relative density and absolute density were used in [30] to remove noise samples and calculate sparsity and boundary weights to generate more new samples in the boundary of positive-class samples and sparse regions.

sec.title: 2.5. Literature Review
sec.p: All of the above literature works have proposed effective improvement measures for the synthetic oversampling methods for imbalanced datasets. However, the improved methods based on the spatial feature and clustering algorithm still rely on the spatial distribution features of samples. The methods based on adaptive interpolation pay too much attention to the synthetic weight of a certain sample, and the methods based on filtering interpolation will lose some precious positive-class samples, meaning that the diversity of the synthetic samples will be lost. At the same time, none of the above-mentioned works have proposed an effective auxiliary sample selection method. Therefore, we propose a synthetic oversampling method based on the safety gradient distribution, which does not depend on the spatial characteristics but determines the root samples, auxiliary samples, and the quantity of generated samples for each gradient interval according to the distribution of samples in the safety gradient intervals and the gradient right nearest neighbor.

sec.title: 3. Method
sec.p: This part mainly introduces the synthetic oversampling method based on gradient distribution proposed in our work. Firstly, the concepts involved in the proposed method are introduced in Section 3.1, including the gradient contribution, safety gradient interval, danger gradient interval, critical safety interval, and critical danger interval. The technologies involved in GDSMOTE and the overall framework are introduced in Section 3.2, and Section 3.3 shows the algorithmic flow of the GDSMOTE method. Section 3.4 provides a summary of the special advantages of GDSMOTE.

sec.title: 3.1.1. Gradient Contribution
sec.p: The cross-entropy gradient of a sample is called the gradient contribution, gc, which is obtained by differentiating the binary classification cross-entropy loss function Lbce from the prediction probability p of the sample. Lbce is calculated as shown in Equation (1), where y is the label of a sample (0 or 1 in the case of binary classification), p is the probability that the classifier predicts this sample to be the positive class, and 1−p is the probability that the classifier predicts this sample to be the negative class. The form of the gradient contribution gcgc∈0,1 is shown in Equation (2), which reflects the gradient contribution of the sample to the classifier and indirectly reflects the difficulty of the sample to be fitted. sec.title: 3.1.2. Safety Gradient Interval and Dangerous Gradient Interval
sec.p: The positive-class samples are divided into k intervals according to gc, and the safety gradient threshold τ is set. The interval whose gradient contribution is less than τ is called the safety gradient interval (SGI), and the interval whose gradient contribution is greater than τ is called the dangerous gradient interval (DGI).

sec.title: 3.1.3. Critical Safety Interval and Critical Dangerous Interval
sec.p: The critical safety interval (CSI) is short for critical safety gradient interval (CSGI), which is the gradient interval whose gradient value is less than the safety gradient threshold τ but closest to τ. The critical dangerous interval (CDI) is short for critical dangerous gradient interval (CDGI), which is the gradient interval whose value threshold is greater than τ but closest to τ. The definitions of these four intervals are shown in Figure 2.

sec.title: 3.2. Overall Framework of GDSMOTE
sec.p: The methodological framework proposed in our work can be described as a combination of four parts. Part 1 is called the sample partition, which assigns the positive-class samples to different gradient intervals and mainly distinguishes the safety gradient interval and the dangerous gradient interval. Part 2 is the safety gradient distribution calculation. The role of this part is to obtain the number of positive-class samples in each safety gradient interval (the safety gradient distribution). Part 3 is called synthesis information determination, in which the root samples, auxiliary samples, and the quantity of samples to generate for each gradient interval are confirmed. Part 4 is linear interpolation, which synthesizes the positive-class samples in a linear interpolation manner according to the synthetic information determined in Part 3. Each part of GDSMOTE will be described in detail (from Section 3.2.1, Section 3.2.2, Section 3.2.3 and Section 3.2.4) and the overall framework of the method is given in Section 3.2.5.

sec.p: The linear interpolation method is used to synthesize pseudo-samples xps for each safety gradient interval according to the synthesis information, as shown in Equation (13), where xrs represents the root sample, xgrnn represents the auxiliary sample, and γ is a set of random numbers in the range of 0 to 1. sec.title: 3.2.5. Methodological Framework
sec.p: The algorithm framework of GDSMOTE is displayed in Figure 3. Dori represents the input class imbalance dataset and Dft is the output of GDSMOTE. We first divide the original data into the majority class dataset Dmaj and the minority class dataset Dmin according to the labels of the samples. Then, we use the logistic regression (LR) model to obtain the prediction probability of each minority-class sample by cross-validation, and the gradient contribution index of each minority-class sample is calculated by Equation (2). This is because the concept of gradient contribution in Equation (2) is obtained by the Lbce loss function, and the loss function of the LR model is Lbce. When the cross-validation result of the LR model is optimal, the prediction probability of each sample is more accurate, so we choose the LR model to calculate the gradient contribution of samples.

Next, each minority class sample is assigned to a different gradient interval based on the gradient interval concept introduced in Section 3.1.2 and the sample partition method introduced in Section 3.2.1. As shown in Figure 3, we have clearly distinguished which samples belong to the SGI (defined in Section 3.1.2) and which samples belong to the DGI (defined in Section 3.1.2) by τ(defined in Section 3.1.2). Then, Equation (7) is used to calculate the safety gradient distribution Q, and Equations (8), (9) and (13) are used to determine the root samples xrs, auxiliary samples xgrnn, and the number of samples to be synthesized for each safety gradient interval, respectively. The final output Dft is obtained by combining the synthetic pseudo-samples Dsmin and the original dataset Dori.

sec.title: 3.3. Algorithm Flow
sec.p:
Based on the basic framework given above, the algorithm flow of GDSMOTE is displayed in Algorithm 1. It can be seen from Algorithm 1 that samples within the safety gradient interval and their gradient right nearest neighbor are selected as the root sample and the auxiliary sample separately. The number of samples to be synthesized in each safety gradient interval is calculated according to the principle of safety gradient distribution approximation. In particular, when the sample with the largest gradient in the interval is taken as the root sample, the sample with the smallest gradient in the next gradient interval is taken as its auxiliary sample; when the sample with the largest gradient in the critical safety gradient interval is taken as the root sample, its gradient right neighbor is the sample with the smallest gradient in the critical danger gradient interval.

sec.title: 3.4. Advantages of GDSMOTE
sec.p: According to the overall framework and algorithm flow of the GDSMOTE method, four special advantages of GDSMOTE can be analyzed.

list-item.p: GDSMOTE divides the positive-class samples into different intervals according to the gradient contribution property of the sample in the training process, which does not depend on the spatial distribution of the sample and avoids the shortcomings of spatial distance measurements and the spatial clustering of high-dimensional samples.

The GDSMOTE method avoids the error accumulation of noise samples to some extent. In the GDSMOTE method, the noise samples, which are difficult to fit, are in the dangerous gradient interval, and the samples in the dangerous gradient interval are not selected as root samples to synthesize pseudo-samples.

The auxiliary sample selection method based on gradient right nearest neighbors ensures that the synthetic sample is in the same gradient interval as the root sample, ensuring that each new sample falls closer to the decision boundary than the root sample.

The gradient contribution of samples synthesized by the GDSMOTE method makes the classification boundary of the model move towards the negative class in a soft way, but it does not obviously lose the recognition performance of negative-class samples.

sec.p: The method based on spatial distance searches for nearest neighbors is shown in Figure 4. The root samples in the dashed circle can only search for auxiliary samples in the dashed circle, and the synthetic samples can only be in the dashed circle. At this point, the synthetic samples may be further away from the decision boundary than the root samples. However, as displayed in Figure 5, when positive-class samples 1 and 2 are selected as root samples, GDSMOTE will select the gradient right nearest neighbor, which is more difficult to fit than the root sample as auxiliary samples, so that the synthetic pseudo-samples must be closer to the decision boundary than the root sample. Consequently, each synthetic sample can effectively drive the decision boundary toward the negative samples.

sec.title: 4. Results
sec.p: In this part, experiments are implemented to verify the performance advantages of GDSMOTE. In Section 4.1, the benchmark algorithm compared with GDSMOTE is introduced, Section 4.2 contains experimental details and the analysis of the results, and hyperparameters are discussed in Section 4.3.

sec.title: 4.1. Benchmark Methods
sec.p: For the sake of demonstrating the performance gain of the GDSMOTE synthetic oversampling method proposed in this paper, eight mainstream synthetic oversampling algorithms for imbalanced classification are selected as benchmark models for experiments, including five methods based on sample space characteristics: SMOTE, ADASYN (adaptive synthetic sampling), BL-SMOTE (borderline-SMOTE), SVM-SMOTE (support vector machine SMOTE), SMOTEN (SMOTE for Nominal), the 1 cluster interpolation method, Kmeans-SMOTE, and 2 mixed sampling methods, SMOTE-Tomek and SMOTE-Edited Nearest Neighbors (SMOTEENN).

sec.title: 4.2. Test Classifiers and Metrics
sec.p: Generalized linear model logistic regression (LR) and the multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural network model are used to test the performance of GDSMOTE methods for the class-balanced optimization of datasets. LR is still widely used in the field of financial risk control because of the interpretability of its prediction results. As a basic component of most neural networks, LR can be used to test the improvement effect of data quality and reflect the role of synthetic oversampling methods in practical applications. MLP is a feedforward network, which is the basic structure of more complex intelligent classification models, so it can represent the fitting ability of classifiers to datasets. Therefore, these two classifiers have a good ability to reflect the optimization performance of imbalanced classification. At the same time, six metrics reflecting the classification performance, F1-score, recall, AUC, G-Mean, MCC, and KS, are selected to reflect the performance of selected classifiers.

sec.title: 4.3.1. Experimental Environment and Dataset Introduction
sec.p: The experiment was conducted on a computer with AMD Ryzen 7 5800H and Radeon Graphics 3.20 GHz CPU and 32 GB memory configuration. The algorithm in the article was written and implemented in Python. Numerical data were mainly processed in the Data Frame structure, without relying on other special software and hardware environments. Our codes for GDSMOTE are available at: https://github.com/tobeoornot/SGDA-for-Sythetic-Oversampling-in-imbalanced-classification (accessed on 3 August 2024).

Two datasets from the UCI platform, an Australian dataset (https://archive.ics.uci.edu/dataset/143/statlog+australian+credit+approval (accessed on 13 September 2024)) and a German dataset (https://archive.ics.uci.edu/dataset/573/south+german+credit+update (accessed on 13 September 2024)), one from the Kaggle platform, Credit Card Fraud Detection (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/mlg-ulb/creditcardfraud (accessed on 14 September 2024)), and one from the Data Fountain platform, Chinese Personal Loans (https://www.datafountain.cn/datasets/6218 (accessed on 15 September 2024)), were selected as our test datasets. Datasets 1–3 are credit default prediction datasets and dataset 4 is a credit card fraud consumption detection dataset They are classical financial imbalance datasets. The sample size and imbalance rate information of these four datasets are shown in Table 1.

sec.title: 4.3.2. Parameters of Test Classifiers
sec.p: The regularization type of the LR classifier is l1, the optimizer is lib-linear, the maximum number of iterations is 200, and the other parameters are default. The number of hidden layers in the MLP classifier is 2, the quantity of nodes in the hidden layer is 100, the regularization parameter is 1 × 10−4 the optimizer is SGD (Stochastic Gradient Descent), the learning rate is 1 × 10−3, and the activation function is tanh.

sec.title: 4.3.3. Experimental Results
sec.p: In this paper, two classifiers, LR and MLP, are selected to prove the performance of the benchmark method and GDSMOTE for class balance optimization on four datasets. For the convenience of description, we number the four datasets as follows: the Australian dataset is dataset 1, the German dataset is dataset 2, Chinese Personal Loans is dataset 3, and Credit Card Fraud Detection is dataset 4. The experimental results on different datasets are shown in Table 2, Table 3, Table 4 and Table 5. GDSMOTE (1) means that the safety gradient threshold of the GDSMOTE method is 1.

The experimental results of GDSMOTE on dataset 1 are shown in Table 2. GDSMOTE achieved the optimal values for all metrics in the MLP classifier, with F1-Score, G-Mean, and KS metrics improving by 6.76%, 2.99%, and 5.12%, respectively, compared to the second-best SVM-SMOTE method, and MCC metrics improving by 7.26% compared to the second-best ADASYN method. For the LR classifier, GDSMOTE achieves the best F1-Score, Recall, G-Mean, and MCC metrics, and the AUC and KS metrics of GDSMOTE have a small gap compared with other optimal methods.

The experimental results of GDSMOTE on dataset 2 are shown in Table 3. The F1-Score, G-Mean, and MCC metrics of both classifiers are all optimal, while the AUC and KS metrics of the MLP classifier are also optimal. Except for the KM-SMOTE method, the Recall value of MLP is also optimal, but the F1-Score value of GDSMOTE is much higher than that of the KM-SMOTE method. The Recall value of the LR classifier is the best except for the SMOTE-ENN method, but the F1-Score value of GDSMOTE is higher than SMOTE-ENN.

The experimental results of GDSMOTE on dataset 3 are shown in Table 4. The F1-Score, G-Mean, MCC, and KS metrics of the two classifiers are all optimal on dataset 3, and the AUC metric of the LR classifier is also optimal. Like its performance on dataset 2, the LR classifier has the best Recall value except for the SMOTE-ENN method, but GDSMOTE has a higher F1-Score value than SMOTE-ENN. The MLP classifier has the highest Recall value except for SMOTE, but the GDSMOTE method has a much higher F1-Score value than SMOTE. It is worth mentioning that GDSMOTE improves the KS metric of the LR classifier by 4.2% compared with the second-best metric.

The experimental results of GDSMOTE on dataset 4 are shown in Table 5. Our experimental results in Table 5 show that the MLP classifier achieved optimal Recall, G-Mean, and MCC values. When the safety gradient threshold of the LR classifier in GDSMOTE is 0.5, the F1-Score, MCC, and KS metrics are all optimal and the GDSMOTE method achieves good Recall values while significantly improving the F1-Score value. Currently, while achieving a high Recall metric, the F1-Score and MCC value of the GDSMOTE method is 10.46% and 9.64% higher than that of the second-best method. When the safety gradient threshold is 0.9, the AUC and MCC metrics are optimal. At this point, GDSMOTE achieved a higher Recall, but still had higher F1-Score values than other methods that obtained similar Recall values.

It can be seen that GDSMOTE not only achieves good Recall metrics but also obtains better F1-Score and MCC metrics than other methods. This indicates that GDSMOTE can improve the accuracy of minority-class samples without sacrificing the accuracy of majority-class samples. In other words, GDSMOTE can avoid the overfitting of minority-class samples.

sec.title: 4.4. Generalization Performance Testing
sec.p: Generalization refers to the predictive ability of a model on a new dataset. Two datasets from the KEEL platform were selected to verify the generalization performance of GDSMOTE, named Yeast6 and Abalone19, and their details are shown in Table 6. They are not datasets for financial scenarios but real datasets from other scenarios.

The experimental results of GDSMOTE on these two datasets are shown in Table 7 and Table 8, respectively. We can see that GDSMOTE makes LR and MLP both obtain optimal Recall, G-Mean, and MCC metrics, and GDSMOTE achieves optimal F1-Score scores, except for the MLP classifier on the Yeast6 dataset, which produces suboptimal metrics. This is consistent with the results obtained on four financial datasets. GDSMOTE can not only improve the recognition accuracy of minority-class samples but also simultaneously maintain the recognition accuracy of majority-class samples, which is higher than other methods. GDSMOTE makes the recognition performance of the classifier more accurate and balanced for different types of samples. Consequently, it can be said that the GDSMOTE method has good generalization performance.

sec.title: 4.5. Comparison with Recent Research
sec.p: In this section, NanBDOS [19] was selected as the comparison method. We compared the F1 Score, AUC, and G-Mean metrics of the MLP classifier on the Yeast6 dataset, and the comparison results are shown in Table 9. From Table 9, it can be seen that all three indicators of GDSMOTE exceed the NanBDOS method. Although NanBDOS adopts a new concept of spatial neighbors, it still relies on the spatial distance measurement of samples. The failure of the spatial distance measurement of high-dimensional samples makes its performance on high-dimensional samples inferior to the GDSMOTE method proposed in this paper, which does not rely on the spatial features of samples.

sec.title: 4.6. Statistical Significance Tests
sec.p: Although the experimental results show that GDSMOTE performs better than the baseline algorithms, we still have to conduct statistical significance experiments to further prove the performance of GDSMOTE. Firstly, the Friedman test is used to verify the performance difference between GDSMOTE and the competing algorithm. Then, our original hypothesis is that there is no performance difference among all synthetic oversampling methods. The results of the Friedman test are shown in Table 10. According to Table 10, it could be concluded that there is a statistically significant difference in performance among the 9 models under six metrics at the 99.99% confidence level, with a high statistical value of 50.8889. This result shows that the performance of the GDSMOTE is significantly different from other competing algorithms.

In addition, in order to compare the differences between the various synthetic oversampling methods, we conducted a Nemenyi test. The heat map of the inspection results is shown in Figure 6. We can see that GDSMOTE is significantly different from five of the comparison algorithms, while there is no significant difference between the eight comparison algorithms.

sec.title: 5.1. Analysis of Results
sec.p: Two aspects of the experimental conclusions are discussed in this subsection.

list-item.p: The framework characteristics of the synthesis oversampling method. GDSMOTE can improve the recognition performance of the positive-class samples without reducing the recognition performance of the classifier for the negative-class samples. This phenomenon shows that the gradient contribution is scientific to partition the sample as an attribute metric of the sample and verifies that the auxiliary sample selection strategy of the gradient right nearest neighbor is a soft way to move the decision boundary to the negative class. At the same time, it shows that the method based on the space features of samples can easily cause overfitting of the positive-class samples due to the problem of small disjuncts or noise samples.

The imbalance rate of the dataset. The experimental results show that on small-scale datasets with low imbalance rates, the best results can be obtained when the safety gradient threshold is close to 1. On large-scale datasets with high imbalance, a satisfactory positive-class sample recognition performance can be obtained when the safety gradient threshold is around 0.5, and the inter-class recognition performance of the classifier is at its most balanced. However, when the safety gradient threshold is around 1, the best positive-class sample recognition performance can be achieved on large-scale datasets with high imbalance, but it will also reduce the recognition performance of negative-class samples.

sec.title: 5.2. Hyperparameter Analysis
sec.p: This section discusses the testing results of the two hyperparameters, numbers of intervals k and the safety gradient threshold τ, of the GDSMOTE method, and the results are displayed in Figure 7. The performance metrics of the classifier on both datasets showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing with the increase in k. When the number of gradient intervals was k=8, the optimal performance of various classifier metrics was achieved on the German dataset, but on the Chinese Personal Loans dataset, the optimal performance was achieved when k=14. The performance metrics of the classifier show an increasing trend with the increase in the safety gradient threshold τ on two datasets. However, on the Credit Card Fraud Detection dataset, in the case of τ=1, the F1-Score and MCC values of the classifier rapidly decrease, indicating that samples with very large gradient contributions can be considered as noisy samples, which also verifies the effectiveness of the gradient contribution metric in measuring sample attributes.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: We propose a new synthetic oversampling method GDSMOTE to solve the problem of imbalance classification. GDSMOTE can improve the recognition ability of the positive-class samples without diminishing the recognition performance of the negative-class samples. Consequently, GDSMOTE can make the recognition ability of different classes more balanced. Our work first introduces the gradient contribution as a metric to measure the attribute of the sample and divides the positive-class samples into different gradient intervals according to the gradient contribution, which overcomes the problem of the difficult-to-measure distances of high-dimensional samples in the space. Secondly, a root sample selection strategy was designed, selecting samples within the safety gradient interval as root samples to avoid error accumulation caused by noisy samples with large gradient contributions. Thirdly, a new concept of gradient right nearest neighbor was proposed, and the gradient right nearest neighbor of the root sample was selected as the auxiliary sample. This not only ensures that the synthetic new sample and the root sample fall within the same gradient interval but also continuously brings the decision boundary closer to the negative-class sample. Finally, a safety gradient distribution approximation principle based on cosine similarity was proposed to calculate the number of samples that need to be synthesized for each gradient interval. The sample distribution synthesized by this principle can avoid the overfitting of positive class samples. The principles can make the decision boundary of the classifier move to the negative class samples in a soft way within the safe range. Finally, our experimental results demonstrate that the gradient contribution can not only reflect the contribution of samples to the classifier but also reflect the noise level of samples.

The GDSMOTE method has two hyperparameters to be tuned, and the optimal group combination of these two hyperparameters on each dataset needs to be manually tuned. Our method relies on the gradient distribution of the minority-class samples. When the gradient distribution of the minority-class samples is extreme, for example, if all the minority samples are concentrated in a certain gradient interval, it may be difficult for our method to play its expected role. In addition, since high-dimensional samples (whether majority samples or minority samples) themselves can easily cause overfitting problems, we will consider incorporating feature selection or feature weighting mechanisms into the synthetic oversampling method to solve the overfitting problem of high-dimensional samples. In the sensitive field of finance, the synthetic samples can only be used to improve the performance of the classifier, and the synthetic samples do not represent the real existence or certain occurrences in reality. Even if our synthetic sample might be very similar to a real customer, it does not necessarily mean that the customer will default.
